>so why do custom teams get the same srank calculation as a solo quer

We don't necessarily know that they do, but if they do the argument that I would jump to would be that *teamwork is a skill too*. Obviously choosing to play with people you understand gives you an advantage, but it's the same principle as someone who practices CSing in customs vs someone who doesn't.

The solo player *could* take the time to add people from their games who they liked/play well with to play in a team for those S ranks, or they could choose to take the disadvantage because they prefer to play solo.

>maybe ARAM's not balanced because people follow metas so hard

ARAM isn't balanced because champions aren't designed for ARAM, they're designed for SR. A champion like Morgana that has powerful team-fighting potential is going to do much better in ARAM than a champion like Kha'Zix who is designed for pick comps just by virtue of their base design.

Twisted Treeline faces some of the same problems, but the fact that you can *pick* from the roster of champions that are effective in TT removes or mitigates most of them because it evolves it's own meta. ARAM doesn't have that luxury.

You kinda lost me a bit in that, but I mentioned CS because CS is a skill just like teamwork. That was my point.

Some people will go out of their way to practice CS and improve that skill, some people won't bother and will just learn by playing the game. In the same manner, some people (of those that don't play with friends) will go out of their way to add people they though played good or they synergised well with and some won't because they don't want to.

In both cases, both are equally valid ways to play the game.

Why should one of those groups in either scenario be denied S ranks simply because they choose to play differently? Should I not be able to get an S rank on Neeko because I'm not playing support in what some people would deem its purest form? From your post, you give the impression that you believe players should have the freedom to play the way they want and be rewarded for it.

As for ARAM, I'm not by any stretch saying that any champ can be adapted for success in ARAM. ARAM Nasus for example usually goes AP which is something that doesn't really work on SR. What I'm saying is that *by design* some champions will have more potential for success than others in ARAM, and some with very low potential, simply because they aren't designed for the team fight centric mode.

I get the impression we'll have to agree to disagree on that one.

TFT is still in beta so there are understandably some things that still need to be addressed, but the max party size for ranked TFT is limited to 3 for this reason (and various others).

In Flex queues, wherever possible the system does queue 5s against 5s, 3+2s against other 3+2s etc, but it isn't always possible. Sometimes the choice will be between 5v5 with one team having a much lower avg MMR, or a 5v3+2 with the latter team having a slightly higher avg MMR which would arguably be better. 

In essence, the system has to pick the best choice from the options it has. Very rarely will the perfect match be one of those options, especially on a low pop server. If the premade dilemma is somethign that's extra important to you for ranked, then you can queue for solo/dup instead. 

I am uncertain what you mean by "mini customs" and this phenomenon being abused for mastery?.

ARAM by nature is not a balanced mode, so ranked is probably not an option. Even with rerolls, it's basically a coin toss and many matches are decided in champ select.

Twisted Treeline is only available at certain times to condense the population into the highest traffic time-slots. Having it up too often spreads the tiny population it has too much and destroys any semblance of queue health and matchmaking.
